title-group.article-title: The Dialectics of Decay: Rereading the Kantian Subject

abstract.p: It is striking that Kant omits the ruin-as emblem and as idea-from his philosophical enterprise, considering the immense popularity of ruins at the end of the eighteenth century. His blindness to the contemporaneous cult of ruins may be emblematic of his own unwillingness to consider the ruination of his overconfident systematics, as well as a less than idealized, or "ruined," subject. While an idealized notion of the Kantian subject has been fundamental to the history of art, the essay demonstrates how the Kantian subject is itself divided, thereby raising questions concerning subjectivity and objectivity in art history.
